awd_titl_txt: Simulations of Laser Experiments to Study the Origin of Cosmic Magnetic Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnetic fields are ubiquitous in the universe. However, their origin is not fully understood. While cosmologists and astrophysicists have proposed a variety of ways in which small seed magnetic fields could be created, the significantly larger values of cosmic magnetic fields we observe are believed to be the result of the amplification of these seed fields by a turbulent flow of plasma, the so-called turbulent dynamo mechanism. This mechanism has not yet been demonstrated in a controlled laboratory environment.  Experiments to demonstrate and study turbulent dynamo in the laboratory are now being planned using the high-intensity lasers at the National Ignition Facility (NIF) at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory and the Laser Megajoule (LMJ) facility in France - the two largest laser facilities in the world.  The effort supported by this award consists of designing and modeling these highly demanding experiments through simulation campaigns using a highly capable code to run large-scale 3D simulations. The simulations are vital to ensuring the experiments achieve the conditions required for the turbulent dynamo mechanism to operate and are crucial to interpreting the results of the experiments. This work will further the transformation of the academic community's ability to design and analyze High Energy Density Physics experiments at large laser facilities and will train junior scientists to design and interpret such experiments using validated simulations - a critical national need.

The experiments to be modeled build on pathfinder experiments that have been conducted on the Vulcan laser at the Rutherford-Appleton Laboratory in the UK and the Omega laser at Laboratory for Laser Energetics at the University of Rochester. They also build on the experience that has been gained designing and interpreting these experiments using validated simulations done with the FLASH code, a highly capable radiation-MHD code developed by the group. The configurations to be used for the NIF and LMJ experiments are based on the platform deployed for the Omega laser, adapted for the large laser facilities using FLASH simulations. The NIF experiment will probe dynamo in the regime of large magnetic Prandtl numbers, the ratio of magnetic-to-fluid Reynolds numbers (Pm = Rm / Re > 1), while the LMJ experiment will focus on magnetic field amplification for Pm < 1. The dynamo mechanism is expected to operate differently in each regime and FLASH simulations will ensure the experiments reach the required plasma states. These experiments promise to characterize the distribution of turbulent energy among the velocity, magnetic field, and density fluctuations, providing a comprehensive picture of the energy cascade in a magnetized, turbulent plasma. Since the number of laser shots per shot day is only two at NIF and three at LMJ, there is no room for error: numerical modeling to design and analyze the experiments is imperative to accomplish the scientific goals of demonstrating and characterizing the turbulent dynamo mechanism.

por.por_cntn:
Here we report the Project Outcomes of the NSF/DOE Partnership in Basic Plasma Science and Engineering project "Simulations of Laser Experiments to Study the Origin of Cosmic Magnetic Fields" (PI: P. Tzeferacos, co-PI: D. Q. Lamb).

Intellectual merit. The goal of the project was to design and model experimental campaigns, performed by the TDYNO (turbulent dynamo) collaboration on high-power laser facilities in the US and France, which aimed to demonstrate and study turbulent dynamo, a ubiquitous astrophysical process that is believed to be responsible for present-day cosmic magnetic fields. The simulations were performed using the FLASH code and guided the experimental platform design for each facility to ensure that the experiments achieved the plasma conditions required for the mechanism to operate; informed the timing and configuration of the experimental diagnostics; and enabled the interpretation of the results of the experiments.

The project enabled (1) the first experimental demonstration of turbulent dynamo in subsonic turbulence in the small magnetic Prandtl number regime at the OMEGA Laser Facility at the Laboratory for Laser Energetics, University of Rochester, (2) the first experimental demonstration of turbulent dynamo in subsonic turbulence in the large magnetic Prandtl number regime at the National Ignition Facility (NIF), Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, and (3) the first experimental demonstration of magnetic field amplification in supersonic turbulence at the Laser Megajoule Facility (LMJ) in France, the first academic experiment ever performed on that facility.

The project also resulted in the development of a new method for reconstructing path-integrated magnetic fields from proton radiographs in the linear and non-liner regimes, as well as a new experimental diagnostic at the OMEGA Laser Facility for measuring magnetic field strengths using Faraday rotation. The proton radiography reconstruction techniques were implemented into two open-source codes, PRaLine and PROBLEM, which were made publicly available on the GitHub repository of the Flash Center for Computational Science and were also distributed with the FLASH code public releases. Throughout the course of the project, we enhanced the capabilities in the FLASH code to enable higher fidelity simulations of laser-driven experiments and introduced an extensive suite of state-of-the-art synthetic diagnostics including proton radiography, optical Thomson scattering, and Faraday rotation. These capabilities were made widely available in the public releases of the FLASH code. Further, the simulations performed for this project informed the design of additional experimental campaigns that studied the transport of high-energy particles in magnetized turbulence, laser-produced blast waves, and the acceleration of electrons by wave turbulence.

The experimental demonstration of turbulent dynamo had been a long-sought goal in plasma astrophysics and the breakthrough was reported by online news outlets and the scientific press. The PI, the co-PI, and members of the TDYNO collaboration were awarded by the American Physical Society the 2019 John Dawson Award for Excellence in Plasma Physics Research "for innovative experiments that demonstrate turbulent dynamo in the laboratory, establishing laboratory experiments as a component in the study of turbulent magnetized plasmas, and opening a new path to laboratory investigations of other astrophysical processes." 

Broader impacts. The project supported the training of young scientists to design and interpret high energy density physics (HEDP) experiments using validated FLASH simulations. More specifically, the project engaged two University of Chicago Postdoctoral Scholars: Dr. Scott Feister and Dr. Benjamin Khiar, and - through the NSF portion of the award - four University of Chicago undergraduate researchers: Alemayehu Bogale, Jordan Laune, Yousef Lawrence, and Christopher Walker. Dr. Feister led the simulation analysis of the NIF experimental campaign, whereas Dr. Khiar led the simulation analysis of the LMJ experimental campaign. The undergraduate researchers actively assisted these analyses and contributed also with code development of auxiliary software. The project furthered the Flash Center's efforts to transform the academic community's ability to use numerical simulations to design and analyze HEDP experiments at large laser facilities. This was made possible by the successful application of the code to simulate the highly demanding OMEGA, NIF, and LMJ experimental campaigns, and with the availability of FLASH and its adoption by the academic HEDP community.
